title: John Mueller at Google: Insights Every SEO Should Read
description: Want to know John Mueller‚Äôs latest tips and tricks for digital success? Read this article to get the inside scoop on SEO straight from the horse's mouth.
content: Blog / SEO Strategy / Insights from Google‚Äôs John Mueller: Key Lessons for SEOsInsights from Google‚Äôs John Mueller: Key Lessons for SEOs Written by Daria Chetvertak Reviewed by Olena Karpova Dec 22, 2023 16 min read Now, you‚Äôve probably already reached out to other well-known SEO experts to address all sorts of website optimization issues. And you‚Äôd be hard-pressed not to have come across John Mueller‚Äôs various quotes along the way. Being one of Google‚Äôs top voices, Mueller is extraordinarily talented at cooling people‚Äôs doubts while also keeping Google‚Äôs secrets safe and sound. John has been a guiding hand for those who may not align with Google‚Äôs guidelines and is an advocate for the creation of really useful, unique, non-generic websites and quality content. He supports the concept of ‚ÄúMaking the web you want to find‚Äù. All that being said, if you work in the SEO industry, you need to keep John‚Äôs statements close to the chest. In this article, we will talk about John Mueller and his role at Google. We‚Äôll also go over any of Mueller‚Äôs SEO insights that you may have missed. Who is Google‚Äôs John Mueller? John Mueller is the Senior Webmaster Trends Analyst and Search Relations team lead at Google. You might also know him as the Google Search Advocate. Instead of diving head first into John‚Äôs SEO insights and recommendations, let‚Äôs start by taking a quick look at his background and career history before and during his experience at Google. This will help you understand why it‚Äôs important to listen to his advice if you haven‚Äôt already. Before Google John Mueller was born in Germany, but was raised in both the US and Switzerland. He received his higher education in Mechanical Engineering at ETH Zurich, a Swiss university. Before joining Google in 2007, he owned a software company in Switzerland for more than 12 years. Career at Google John Mueller‚Äôs start at Google began in September 2007. It's apparently been 14 years at Google for me now. Every year I'm tempted to write a retrospective. Most years, the time around early September has been too stressful & annoying for me. Other years I wrote on internal Google+, but that's gone, and Currents just isn't my thing. pic.twitter.com/AUSXQp9bvY‚Äî John (@JohnMu) September 3, 2021 Being a Google Search Advocate, he focuses on helping webmasters and site owners understand how Google search works and how to improve their sites. In fact, he connects the Google-internal world of search engineering, to those who create and optimize public websites. He‚Äôs also known for his regular Google SEO Office Hours, where he holds live Q&As with webmasters and SEOs. He regularly joins webmaster-related forums and speaks at industry conferences. Mueller is also active on Twitter and LinkedIn, and is generally available to answer users‚Äô questions. SEO insights from John Mueller Now, let‚Äôs move on to the most exciting part: Mueller‚Äôs insights. Coming from someone who knows Google‚Äôs inner workings and is genuinely eager to help you, expect nothing short of gold. Each of John‚Äôs statements is grouped by category to help you find info within your topic of interest. What SEOs are doing wrong The primary goal of optimizing a website is to help Google find (and understand) your content. But some people make the mistake of thinking SEO is about manipulating search results to get higher rankings. Manipulating results actually dampens SERP quality. When lower-quality content somehow reaches the top, this makes users‚Äô lives more difficult and motivates Google to work even harder to fix its algorithms. Mueller has his own opinion on this. SEO tricks like these go against Google‚Äôs guidelines. You might get temporary results, sure, but they‚Äôll almost always lead to long-term failure. That means you want to play fair, which also means you‚Äôll be playing the SEO long game. Remember that SEO involves many processes, has an accumulative effect in some aspects, and requires constant effort. This can take the form of tasks like maintaining your site‚Äôs overall relevance, responding to Google‚Äôs constantly evolving algorithms, keeping an eye on competitors, and much more. About the long game of SEO, from @robertbalazsihttps://t.co/VVbNduemYG‚Äî John (@JohnMu) December 23, 2021 John Mueller supports genuine SEO. He often stresses how important it is to create search results that users value. According to Mueller, there‚Äôs no magical formula for propelling your website to the top spot in Google. ‚ÄúUnfortunately there‚Äôs more to online success than just adding more pages. On the one hand, it‚Äôs important that things which you add actually bring new & unique value to the web. On the other hand, it‚Äôs important that your site overall is unique, compelling, of high quality, and also brings value to the web in ways that users recognize. None of this is trivial, it can take a lot of hard work to figure out what to focus on, where to expand, and where to simplify. And sometimes, it is possible to commit no mistakes and still not win. In short: there is no simple secret to online success.‚Äù There is also no perfect SEO. ‚ÄúThe internet, search engines and how user‚Äôs search is always changing. So SEO will evolve over time as well. This includes both technical elements, like structure data, as well as considerations around quality.‚Äù Constantly searching for universal SEO tips and applying them to your site is not the way to go. Instead, Mueller advises investing time in creating valuable and unique content that is engaging and brings something new to the table. Be sincere to your audience and honest with Google. Keep in mind that having good search results takes a team effort. Google must work on improving search, and website owners must improve the quality of their pages. Content The quotes below following the theme of content optimization, a key area in SEO. John actually talks about this concept a lot. Keyword stuffing is not as dangerous as it seems. It‚Äôs common for SEOs to worry about having too many repeated keywords on their pages. The general consensus is that Google may interpret this behavior as an attempt to manipulate the website‚Äôs ranking. But having a high number of keyword entries is okay as long as the content remains useful to the reader. So whether it‚Äôs appropriate to include 10 or 100 keywords depends entirely on the content. This suggests that you should focus on quality over quantity. 10-20x is amateur numbers when it comes to keyword stuffing :-). I would think of it more as "does this annoy users when they go to my page" and take action based on that.‚Äî John (@JohnMu) August 2, 2023 I didn't want to downplay the worry ‚Äì it's just that when I run across pages where *I* worry about keyword stuffing, it's usually on the order of 3-500+ mentions on a page. I wouldn't worry about 10-20 mentions on a page just for SEO, but I *would* check if users think it's ok. pic.twitter.com/RRyYAvLTKb‚Äî John (@JohnMu) August 2, 2023 Short content can still rank high. Sometimes lengthy content is actually less valuable. For example, let‚Äôs say that a user is looking for a quick and precise answer to their question. A short post would have much better performance in this case than a long one. Some experts still believe that content must have a specific word count (let‚Äôs say, minimum 500 or 1000 words) to rank better, but even if this was partially true in the past, it‚Äôs not true at all now. As of today, word count has no direct impact on your ranking whatsoever. Your website will not be penalized if it‚Äôs missing an H1 tag or has multiple on your page. The H1 heading is an important element for structuring your content, but the absence of an H1 tag doesn‚Äôt necessarily have to spell disaster. Google‚Äôs algorithms are designed to understand webpage content, regardless if it includes an H1 tag or not. In fact, there are many websites that have high rankings but don‚Äôt use H1 tags. Comment byu/ruggy229 from discussion inSEO John Mueller has also confirmed that Google doesn‚Äôt have any issues with pages that have multiple H1 tags. ‚ÄúOur systems don‚Äôt have a problem when it comes to multiple h1 headings on a page. That‚Äôs a fairly common pattern on the web. We use headings to better understand the context of different parts of a page. Our systems aren‚Äôt too picky and we‚Äôll try to work with the HTML as we find it, be it one H1 heading, multiple H1 headings or just styled pieces of text without semantic HTML at all.‚Äù Using multiple H1 tags is common practice among single-page websites. Word location in URLs does not matter for SEO. Many believe that word location within the URL impacts rankings, especially if it refers to e-commerce websites. The reasoning here is that they think it‚Äôs crucial to place /services/ before /location/ in the URL. But this really is not the case. All this does is influence the user experience and won‚Äôt provide any substantial benefits to search engines. Backlinks Next up on Mueller‚Äôs list of insights is off-page SEO. This is one of the main components of a successful website promotion strategy. Domain authority is not a ranking factor. Many SEO beginners think domain authority directly impacts Google rankings. But John Mueller reminds us that that‚Äôs not the case at all. You can ignore spammy backlinks. You can‚Äôt track all toxic backlinks. There is not much you can do about it anyway and spammers are going to be spammers. This is why John advises not to be overly concerned about links like these. If you weren‚Äôt buying links, don‚Äôt disavow. Google historically has not been a fan of folks using the disavow file. They even doubled down on it recently, so avoid doing it because it tends to do more harm than good anyway. The donor website‚Äôs type doesn‚Äôt directly impact off-page SEO. Some SEOs used to think that sites like news sources had more ranking power because they were considered ‚Äúauthority sites.‚Äù But that theory fell flat a long time ago. John Mueller recently clarified that all sites are treated the same, and what matters for PageRank is the site‚Äôs structure and how often it publishes content. The other thing to keep in mind is that different kinds of sites have vastly different internal architectures. A site constantly publishing new content is extremely different from a stable reference site. Think about how pagerank works, if you want to be technical.‚Äî John (@JohnMu) April 11, 2023 Technical SEO Unlike on-page and off-page SEO (which focus on content and external factors), technical SEO often deals with the backend aspect of a site. It sets the foundation for the website‚Äôs overall SEO strategy. That being said, let‚Äôs find out John‚Äôs take on technical SEO. Technical SEO still matters. Mueller recently confirmed that technical SEO is still important. He has rejected claims that its significance is decreasing and believes that technical SEO is essential to ranking well in search engines. It also plays a key role in providing a good user experience, which is the most important factor. As long as machines read websites, technical SEO will remain an important part of making the most out of a website. It's not going away. And as long as humans look at websites, performance and user-experience is going to remain just as important. No amount of links replace these.‚Äî John (@JohnMu) April 26, 2023 Google Quality Updates may affect crawling and indexing. Any changes made after updates affect more than just search positions. They also impact crawling and indexing. John Mueller reminded us of this on Mastodon: Good Core Web Vitals don‚Äôt guarantee good rankings. While CWVs will be used for ranking, they won‚Äôt instantly propel your website from page 10 to the number one position. Recently, John emphasized this point in the context of launching a new Interaction to Next Paint (INP) metric, which will replace First Input Delay, in March 2024. ‚ÄúWhile improving INP can definitely help user experience, I wouldn‚Äôt expect it to visibly change search ranking.‚Äù He also stated recently that Cumulative Layout Shift can‚Äôt be the reason for sudden ranking drops. That‚Äôs it, Core Web Vitals is an important thing for users, but it‚Äôs not going to change everything completely. HTML sitemaps should never be needed. If you already have a clear navigational structure, why would you need an HTML sitemap that duplicates the same structure of your site? Now, it probably won‚Äôt cause problems, but, according to John Mueller, there‚Äôs no incentive to do it. Your best is to focus instead on improving the site structure. Google may choose a syndication partner as the canonical source to rank. If your website syndicates its content to partners, be prepared for the chance that Google will decide, for whatever reason, that the partner‚Äôs site is the canonical source and award that position to them. Recently, John Mueller confirmed this on X: Hi Lily! It's complicated, and not all the things you're asking about are things we necessarily even use. In general, if we recognize a page as canonical, that's going to be the page most likely rewarded by our ranking systems.‚Äî John (@JohnMu) January 31, 2024 To prevent this issue, you can ask partner websites to use the noindex tag. Update the URL address in Google Search Console when performing a website migration. It‚Äôs recommended to update the URL address in Google Search Console during (not before) the migration. Google lacks data for the analysis of empty space, so it doesn‚Äôt make sense to change the URL address before the migration starts. It‚Äôs better to do it during migration because there will already be content on the new site for the search engine to process. When you do the migration.‚Äî John (@JohnMu) January 30, 2024 Having the wrong last modification date in your HTTP header won‚Äôt impact SEO. It‚Äôs good to use last-modification date headers appropriately. This helps Google estimate how often pages are updated and to adjust its crawling more efficiently, but John Mueller says that neglecting this or doing it wrong won‚Äôt hurt your SEO. Resources to follow for Mueller‚Äôs SEO insights Mueller has been using various channels to shed light on key optimization aspects for website owners and SEO experts. He publishes posts on both X (Twitter) and Mastodon. He participates in Google Webmaster Central and even hosts Google SEO Office Hours. In the sections below, you‚Äôll get an in-depth look into each one of these resources. We recommend exploring and subscribing to them, or adding them to your bookmarks. We‚Äôre confident that each of these resources will be valuable to you! Search News in Google Search Central Blog & YouTube Google Search Central serves as the main hub for webmasters and SEO practitioners. There they have access to official guidance, best practices, and updates from Google. In the Google Search Central Blog, you can find posts by John Mueller. These posts are generally about changes in search or updates about Google SEO Office Hours. Google Search Central also has its own YouTube channel, where John shares regular updates. These can be found in the Google Search News section. Here‚Äôs one of his video updates: Search Central Live If you prefer in-person workshops, try Google Search Central Live events! Search Central Live started in 2019 under the Webmaster Conference name. Since then, John Mueller has been participating in them. Recently, in October 2023, Mueller participated in Search Central Live Zurich to deliver an insightful speech on changes happening in Google Search. It's happening. pic.twitter.com/7tvUX50WbC‚Äî John (@JohnMu) October 24, 2023 Note that these events do not have video coverage or live translations. To gain insights from the workshop, you‚Äôll need to request an invitation and attend the event in person. Check out this calendar of upcoming SEO events and workshops to see where John Mueller will be next. Google SEO Office Hours Google SEO Office Hours are video sessions conducted in Q&A format. Each is hosted by Google‚Äôs Search Quality team, with John Mueller as the team‚Äôs permanent host. During these sessions, Mueller addresses submitted questions and offers advice pertaining to optimizing websites for Google Search. In fact, many people are familiar with Mueller precisely because of these sessions. Website owners and SEO professionals worldwide use these sessions to get their SEO questions answered and to receive guidance directly from Google. See here the list with all these videos. All are published monthly. If text content is more your speed, you can find all the transcripts here. By the way, John Mueller also hosts another video series on the Google Search Central YouTube channel called #AskGooglebot. This format is similar to Google SEO Office Hours, but in each video in this series, John answers just one question. If you‚Äôd like to have your question answered by John in future videos, you can either submit it using this Google form or post your question on X (Twitter). Don‚Äôt forget to include the hashtag #AskGoogleBot. Search Off The Record podcast Search Off the Record is another media channel that John Mueller participates in. In podcast format, Mueller and other pros from the Search Relations team give you background info on the decision-making behind launches, feature prioritization in Search Console, and the projects Google Search teams are working on. They also share fun stories from the many conferences they attend, plus their day-to-day life working at Google. X (Twitter) This is the most informal channel, but it‚Äôs one of the most engaging. On X (Twitter) John shares all sorts of SEO insights. He often provides quick answers to users‚Äô questions, shares important announcements, Google-related news, expert tips, and, of course, adds a touch of humor with plenty of SEO (and other) memes. Search Console, Search Console, what you got for me? #bard @googlesearchc pic.twitter.com/EcGLwkVnHV‚Äî John (@JohnMu) September 22, 2023 To receive bite-sized SEO information in an entertaining format, then following John on X (Twitter) is a must. Try asking him questions and mentioning him in your tweets, and who knows? You may just get a response or a retweet üòâ Mastodon John is also actively managing an account on Mastodon. Here, you can find various announcements and Google news. He also uses this medium to reply to webmasters‚Äô questions. If you have a Mastodon profile, we recommend following John to stay informed. You won‚Äôt want to miss out on anything important from the Google world. Conclusion John Mueller offers tons of valuable information for anyone involved in SEO. That‚Äôs why you absolutely must pay attention to what he‚Äôs doing and what he‚Äôs learned along the way. From debunking common myths to shedding light on intricate aspects of website optimization, Mueller‚Äôs expertise and practical experience make his advice crucial for navigating the complex world of SEO. Our advice for the future: keep up with Mueller‚Äôs talks and posts. Don‚Äôt miss anything important. And always run your website by following Google‚Äôs best practices. Get these down pat, and Google (and your users) will reward you. SEO Mistakes Website Promotion 2118 views Written by Daria Chetvertak Daria is a content marketer at SE Ranking.
